Response: NA; we didn't have any changes

We have a functional process to identify patients that will be part of BPCI-A program.  We have a nurse navigator that follows patients while in patient, develops discharge plan and continues foll up through 90 day period.  We have engaged keep post acute care providers and worked collaboratively with them to develop enhanced communication channels to avoid unnecessary trips to ED.   We have good data tracking systems in place to understand our utilization.

Our readmission rate has dropped considerably compared to our base period data.  The acute rehabilitation facility that sees our patients has much bettter communication with our neurology physicians and our Stroke Bundle Nurse Manager.  Our PT department has been integrally involved and is conducting early assessments of patients while inpatient that may be candidates to good home after inpatient stay.
All of our physicians are employees of the Capital Health Medical Group and use the same EMR (AthenaHealth) that meets CEHRT requirements.
All of the physicians are Capital Health Medical Group employees. As such we contracted with the medical group as opposed to the individual physicians.

The risk remains with our convener organization, Population Health Management Services, LLC.  Since PHMS and the Episode Initiators are all owned by the same parent organization, Capital Health System, we did not feel it was necessary to create downstream risk agreements.
NA; we don't participate in ICS Sharing
We are contracted with Premier Bundled Payment Collaborative which analyzes our CMS claims data and tracks our financial performance.

While not a formal plan, we have overlap in responsibilities on the BPCI-A  staffing that would allow the remaining team members to pick up responsibilities if one of our team members left the organization.  Our clinical team includes 3 RNs (Director, Manager, Staff Nurse) that are all familiar with the care management processes.  These nurses are further supported by a physician.  If any one of these nurses left, the others could pull together to keep our processes in place until a replacement could be found and hired.  On the administrative side, we have a Director and VP that share responsibilities which are also supported by a physician (same physician that supports the clinical area).

Our regular BPCI-A steering committee originally met on a bi-weekly basis and now meets monthly.  This committee consists of neuro science physicians, nurse practitioners, hospitalists, hospital administrators, care management, quality management and physical and occupational therapy. This working group has helped resolved several process issues that were impacting care for stroke patients that were part of the BPCI-A program as well as non-BPCI patients.  Providing data on utilization to the groups has spurred healthy discussion on how to make improvements on placing patients post discharge as well as how to avoid unnecessary ED visits and how to better manage patients that do return to the ED.

We review utilization data to identify unusual variations in patterns of care.  When unusual trends are identified, further research and/or analysis is conducted to better understand what has caused the change in utilization patterns and if these changes are reasonable.

We need to put this in place.  That said, the overwhelming amount of email and communication about BPCI-A makes it difficult to suss out what is urgent or has a deadline from simply informative information.  In the MSSP ACO program, we have a newsletter that highlights all important changes and we have a liaison that meets with us regularly by telephone to keep us on track of what needs to be done.  The ACO model for communication is much more effective.

Having a liaison (similar to MSSP) to be able to answer questions or provide information/explanation of program requirements would be helpful.The paperwork and contracting requirements are fairly overwhelming.It would be helpful to receive claims data on a more routine and timely basis.Having more benchmark data from CMS on how other participants are doing compared to our organization to help us identify areas for potential improvement would be helpful.
